text: On tap at Anvil & Stave. Dark brownish/amber with a small head. Aroma of malt, bourbon, caramel, some nuts and hints of vanilla. The body was on the soft side. A rather interesting one.

Not much barrrel in this beer. Very thin mouthfeel on this one. Some what Nutty and malty. Bette than the standard nut brown 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at the brewery. Pours a cloudy brown with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is toasted malt, wood, booze. Medium body, toffee, wood, cocoa, light booze finish, very good.

Draft @ the brewery. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel woody bourbon aroma. Fruity malty woody caramel flavor. Has a fruity malty woody caramel finish with weak hints of vanilla.

Pours a hazy golden brown on tap with bubbly off-white head that leaves light lace. Aroma of big barrel notes over a hint of toasty nut and dark malts. Taste follows, barrel is huge, impressive for a small abv beer. Balance is a little off, body is a little thin, but cool stuff, keeping the barrel aged there for people who dont want high alcohol.
sample at the brewery, tough to balance all this sweetness in this one. Nuts, molasses, and vanilla dominate aroma, taste, and finish.
On tap at Alesmith. Poured dark amber brown with off white head. Aroma light vanilla barrel. Light carb med bod. Taste sweet barrel juice.
On draft at the brewerry. Pours black with a tan head. Nutty aroma. Flavors of toffee and bourbon. Vanilla notes. Roast finish.

Draft. Specifically noted as the 2016 vintage, and as "Bourbon Barrel Aged." Pours deep brown with a beige head. Nutty malts and chocolate sweet base, lighter bourbon barrel presence, some mild husky notes, and a nice quick finish. Not a ton of booze at all; very easy drinking.

Sample at Anvil & Stave. Dark reddish-brown color with a medium light beige head that recedes steadily to a film. Small patched of lacing on the glass. Oak, nuts and malt in the nose. Light to medium body with flavors of bourbon roasted malt and nuts. The finish is oaky and nutty with a subtle bourbon aftertaste. Pretty good overall.

Draft enjoyed in the Speakeasy room. Nice chestnut color with a tan head. Aroma is coffe and dark malt with a hint of molasses. Flavor is more coffee plus some light sweetness and booze. Maybe a touch thin but nice for a brown and 5 ABV.

Draught at the brewery. Pours clear brown with a medium, frothy white head, medium retention with good lacing. Aroma is moderate nutty and toast malt, oak and light bourbon with soft figs and chocolate. Flavor is moderate nutty and toast malt, dates, oak, light Bourbon and a dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.
Takes away a touch of complexity from the really nice base beer, but also adds layers of vanilla, bourbon and wood. Call it a wash, perhaps. All versions Ive had are quite good. On tap @Alesmith.
Really good. Nuttiness with earthy malt and undertones of wood and bourbon. Soft brown color with a thin head. Smooth and weighty.

Taster showing opaque caramel brown. 

The nose shows sweet sugar cane. 

The palate shows a tea-like forwardness with bourbon woodiness in the background. Light bodied and moderately carbonated with a slight astringency on the end.

A reddish copper ale with a thick creamy brown head. In aroma, sweet caramel malt with light bourbon barrel notes, peaty notes, dark fruits, molasses, nice. In mouth, a sweet fruity caramel malt with light candy sugar, light bourbon and vanilla, licorice notes, alcohol warmth, very nice. On tap at brewery.

Draft at the source. Poured a dark brown color with a small tan head. Aroma was notes of nutty bourbon roast, light toffee, bourbon character. Flavor was roasted malts, nutty notes. Barrel nicely compliments the beer.

Draught @ AleSmith Tasting Room, San Diego, CA

Pours dark brown, almost black with a smooth head. Aroma of roasty malts, coffee, cocoa, vanilla, oak and hints of bourbon. Taste is smooth, slightly roasty and oaky with some coffee, cocoa, hints of vanilla and bourbon. Finish is smooth, sweetish and slightly roasty. Quite smooth, yet complex and balanced.
Draught @ Alesmith, Miramar. Aroma has coffee, nutty malt and chocolate. Flavour has sweet bourbon tones, coffee, some nuts and chocolate. Smooth, easy to drink and delicious.

Tap @ brewpub, San Diego.
Pours deep dark red color with a small head. Nuts and caramel on the nose, bourbon, faint vanilla and wood. Sweet caramel flavor, nuts, bourbon and vanilla. Smooth and tasty.
4325

28 July 2015, tap at AleSmith. Brown/black. Nose is sweet, lightly nutty, sweet wheat bread, some bourbon oak. Full body and mildly fizzy. Sweet, ovaltine, bourbon. Its weird, this is the lowest abv beer Ive ever had that was barrel aged. Im realizing that alcohol and sugars contribute so much more to these beers than I realized. This is okay but not great.

Taster at the brewery. Brown-amber color with white fine foam. Like the original Nut Brown: a greatly balanced nutty-earthy experience, just here we have hints of bourbon wood and vanilla going on. Carbonation is quite present for a BA beer. Great and subtle addition to the already good Nut Brown.

(En fût à la brasserie): Beurre de noisette, vanille et une généreuse portion de brown malt. Lintensité des saveurs est superbement proportionnelle à sa buvabilité. Une des meilleures petite bière vieillie en fût de bourbon, une combinaison qui ne fonctionne pas souvent pour moi.

Keg at the brewery, to wash down the Speedway Grand Prix, 14/11/14.
Dark mahogany brown with a moderate tan swirl and edgeing.
Nose is raisens, dates, biscuit Jacobs Club bar, subtle bourbon, nutty.
Taste comprises dark fruit rinds, spice, bourbon, sweet licks, toasted brown sugar, raisens, trace cocoa.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close.
Decent subtle BA take on the base.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Draft at the brewery. Pours clear copper brown with a fizzy off white head. Tastes like nutty roasted malt, booze, woody, earthy. Light body and low carbonation. Smells nutty, like booze, roasted malt, dried fruits, earth, wood.

On tap at their tasting room. On nitro. Pours dark brown with a creamy off white head. Bourbon and oak on the nose. Flavor follows. Sweet slight dark chocolate. Really nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
One of the best beers I ever had. Good with cheese. nice brown color. Sweet and full body.

Biscut and choc aroma come from this clear brown beer with a small off white head. It has a typical dry english taste with a bit of choc and biscut with a light body. Not a bad tast tho i didnt get a nut flavor but a good brew none the less.

kcorum with the growler score. Medium brown color, light brown head. Roasted nuts, cocoa and the lightest of barrel hints. I think this must have been in the barrel maybe 3..4 hours? Kidding...but the barrel is very faint.

Growler share courtesy of kcorum10. It pours with a clear amber body that has copper edges and supports a light tan head. The aroma has nice rich nuttiness, some roasted malts and very light subtle barrel notes off in the background. The taste is similar with a pleasing nuttiness, sort of smooth light vague barrel notes and some roasted malts around the edges. Solid brown.
Tap at Alesmith. Good foam, clear deep red brown. Excellent bourbon nose, buttery, toasted coconut, hazelnut. Taste is pretty straight forward with milk chocolate, lemon, a tad chalky in palate.

Tap at the brewery - San Diego. Pours clear brown with a fine, creamy tan head. The nose hold some tangy berries, a bit of bread and toffee. Medium sweet flavor with toffee, fruity pudding, semi-dried fruits, berries, hints of sugary chocolate. Medium bodied with fine, creamy carbonation. Well balanced to finish with further ripening berries, hints of leathery fruits, toffee and cocoa. Well balanced and very tasty.

Growler sampled @ Daks Black Friday tasting. Dark mahogany pour with a small latte foam. Caramel malt, toasted oak, burnt marshmallow, coffee, and cocoa. Small hint of bourbon. The barrel aging seemed to add some body to this one. A good beer for the style.

On tap at brewery. Very dark brown with a fizzy tan head. Bourbon, vanilla, caramel, roasted grain, and nuts aroma and taste with light coffee notes. Bright and smooth palate. Nicely balanced. Quite good.
On tap at alesmith, aroma is sweet malt and little roast, taste is similar with a sweet booze finish, nice!

Draft at brewery. Pours very dark brown with a khaki head and a shitload of lacing. I get a faint whiff of the whiskey on the nose. The whiskey is subdued in the langue which is good since you can still pick out the nut brown notes. Finishes clean. Subtle and a nice drinker.

On tap @ Alesmith. Pours dark brown with big off white head. Aroma of this is oak, vanilla, and bourbon with some nutty scents. Taste is sweet caramel, malt, oak, vanilla and a nutty faint milk chocolate. Good balance, good carbonation and a very good brown ale.

On tap at AleSmith tasting room. Pours a deep brown colour, hazy with a big beige head. Aroma is not as strong as the regular nut brown ale but there is distinct oak presence within it that likely mutes some of the other scents. Taste is malty sweet with less perceptible bitterness than the regular nut brown ale. Really creamy on the palate, softer carbonation , and medium bodied. A very nice barrel aged beer.

Pours a dark brown with a surprising off-white head. A lot of smoke on the nose, roasted nuts, and toffee. Mouthfeel is silky smooth. Oaky, bourbony, and caramel flavors. The nose didnt quite prepare me for how good this beer is. Theres a little coffee acidity at the finish that knocks this beer off of perfect. Not to say coffee acidity is bad, just doesnt fit here.
Bottle. Brown with a small head. Malty with a slight spiceness. Different and quite interesting.

Growler... Clear brown ale with flickers of burnt-orange and a small, creamy, khaki head. The bouquet is a luxuriant mélange of candied pistachios and almonds with a light kiss of vanilla. Medium-bodied and chewy with modest carbonation. The flavor is sweet cream soda accentuated by hints of caramel, milk chocolate and toasted nuts. Sweet vanilla finish. Bourbon barrel? Really? Darn good English brown ale either way. Growler generously provided by richiesd!

Draft Alesmith tasting room. Brown in color... duh... Nose is nutty with just a slight presence of bourbon noticable. Taste follows the nose.... roasted malts, nutty flavor, perfect amount of bourbon noticable without being the dominate flavor. Creamy smooth and easy to drink. Overall: Very enjoyable.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a dark brown with a malty oaky nose. Taste is nutty with oak easily tasted. Finishes nicely. Quaff Score 8  / 10

On tap at Ale Smith brewery. Pours a dark brown with a brown head and aroma of nuts and oak. Taste is nutty, of roasted malt and oak notes as well with a toasty, nutty finish. Great barrel aged brown ale

Pour out of 32 oz growler, thanks a ton Aaron! Dark murky brown pour with off white head, aroma brought notes of nice coconut, vanilla, nuts, cocoa powder, hints of caramel, toffee in there as well, like a coconut macaroon, nice.  Taste is a mix of sweet vanilla, coconut, nuts, toffee, hints of earth, slight spice, more sweet cocoa, finishing fairly sweet, slightly bitter.  While the flavors were nice it was a bit low on the level of flavor.

Poured out of bottle into 5 ounce glass in incriments. Listened to my sis go on and on about her new man but just wanted to get back to the bottle. I like it, its good. Will buy it again if I get the chance.

On tap at the brewery. Pours with a deep brown hued body with a medium sized tan head. Aromas are of cola, nutty, oatmeal, bready, biscuity, vanilla and bourbon. Flavors are nicely malty, vanilla, bready, smooth, light tobacco, cola, medium-low bourbon. Medium body, smooth, somewhat dry, and supremely drinkable!

Growler at Crooked Staves Final Release Party of 2012. Pour courtesy of Aaron, thanks man! Pour is murky brown with a small off-white head and decent lacing. Fairly nutty/toffee aroma, graham crackers, caramel, and a hint of vanilla. Taste is somewhat plain, woddy, oaky, caramel, and nutty. Thin palate with soft carbonation. Not bad, but nothing exciting by any means.

Growler @ Crooked Stave Reserve Society bottle share. Big thanks to womencantsail (A-Dogg!) for this baby! Pours a dark brown appearance with a fairly small, light brown head. Fairly nutty, light bourbon, caramel, mild toffee, coconut aroma. A touch thin body but pretty tasty- caramel, hazelnuts, vanilla, and oak.
I had this on tap at Alesmith. The bourbon flavor complemented the brown ale very nicely. Very nicely done
On tap at Alesmith. Big bourbon vanilla oak nose. Essentially their nut brown, with a nice bourbon/oak character. Very drinkable.

Tap @ Alesmith.  Dark pour with a scattering of tan foam.  Aroma is very light bourbon with underlying nutty roast.  Taste is sweet, decadent bourbon that somehow does not totallydrown out the roast/nutty character of the base beer.  Light and clean mouthfeel but the bourbon lingers.  Very well done.

Taster at Alesmith. Pours dark clear mahogany with a small tan head that leaves nice lacing. Aroma is toffee, bourbon, nutty. Flavor is the same, a bit woody and lightly sweet. A bit of roughness/astringence around the edges. Medium body and prickly carbonation

Tap @ Alesmith...  Poured dark, near black with a bright, khaki head.  Nice lacing on the pint glass.  Nose had nutty malt with some wood and faint whiskey notes.  This was nice.  Little thin though considering the base beer.  A bit sweet and the lack of roast created a nice mix up from the usual BA darker beers.  Other notes of toasted caramel, brûlée and toffee with a hint of vanilla.

Taster at the brewery. Pours a dark brown color with a small beige head. The aroma is dominated by the bourbon, with a faint trace of almonds and pecans poking through. The flavor, like the nose, features a blast of sweet bourbon backed up by mixed nuts, vanilla and some cocoa. The palate was on the lighter side but seemed appropriate for this brew; and the carbonation was medium. Finished with a bourbon flourish. Overall: Good stuff.

Dark brown color with an off-white head. The nose is quite nutty with a nice bourbon and oak aroma. Some vanilla, a bit of coffee, and roasted malt. Good toffee sweetness too. The flavor is heavy on the sweet maltiness and nuttiness. A good bourbon and vanilla character, a bit of oak, and some roasted malt. Light coffee, plenty of chocolate, and some cocoa powder.

On tap at brewery while picking up BA Speedway. Nose is huge malty boozy rich sweet, like a gigantic barley wine. Chocolate and brown sugar. Taste is same. Not nearly as boozy though. Bit of metallic bite. Pulls saliva like a sour. Long rich sweetness. Really big beer. Good for a cold day.
Tap. Rating #7. Hazy dark brown pour. Nutty and a little sweet, light bourbon notes and a good toastiness. Nice stuff. (2532)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Growler from alesmith. Brown reddish pour with thin tan head. Aroma is toasted almonds abd slight cocoa. Taste is vanilla, slight bourbon and nuts.
Draft at the brewery.  Clear brown pour, tan head.  Nutty, dry chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, and oak.  Smooth, and all the flavors really work together nicely.  Quite decadant for a lighter brown ale.
Draught @ AleSmith. Dark brown pour, small tan head. Malts, vanilla, strong bourbon notes. Medium carbonation, a little watery.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2012 On tap at the AleSmith tasting bar: Aroma is nutty with some cocoa and a hint of bourbon. Flavor is nutty with a little bourbon followed some cocoa a hint of smoke and a light dry bitter finish. Medium body is smooth with moderate carbonation.

A great brown ale aged in barrels?  Yes, please.  The bourbon notes ad a great complexity to the nutty, malty notes of this beer.  A little hot, but not overwhelming.  Im amazed at how much bourbon comes through with only 13 days in the barrel.  Thank you sir...may I have another.

12oz, $5 pour at the brewery. One of my favorite browns in a barrel.clear auburn brown with a 1 1/2 finger beige head, good retention. Nice bourbon coconut vanilla nose on top of the hazelnutty base beer. This beer took to the barrel pretty well considering its only been in barrels less than two weeks, per bartender Abby. Flavor again has the bourbon, but in the fresher variety, which, to me, is usually perceived as hot or boozy (which isnt the case here), vs the old oxidized type a la LA Angels Share. Not boozy here at all. A little less coconut, still has vanilla and plenty of hazelnut and some chocolate notes. Semi-dry, bitterness peaked at a 2-3. Low smooth carbonation with a light to medium body. Did not disappoint.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA
